Derek,

I'm not completely sure of the mechanics of your cited 
representat=
ion.  When you say the "top leven gene specifies the 
spatial layout ... of=
 the gene just below it," do you mean "gene" in 
a singular sense?  Or do y=
ou mean that a set of top-level genes that 
specify a layout that lower-lev=
el genes ahere to?

In any case, although it is not exactly the encoding yo=
u have in 
mind, Edwin De Jong and Richard Watson have both done a lot of w=
ork 
on hierarchical encodings and modularity.  This paper is a good 
examp=
le:

De Jong, E.D., Richard A. Watson, and Dirk Thierens (2005). On the 
Co=
mplexity of Hierarchical Problem Solving. Proceedings of the 
Genetic and E=
volutionary Computation Conference GECCO-05. 

That's from Edwin De Jong's =
page: http://www.cs.uu.nl/~dejong/

Note that Richard Watson also did a lot=
 of work on related topics 
independently of Edwin De Jong.

ken


--- In n=
eat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djames@...> wrote:
>
> Hello all,
> 
> =
I'm interested in implementing an indirect encoding scheme in 
which the
> =
genetic representation is a nested hierarchy, e.g.:
> 
> [area][module][neu=
ron]
> 
> Where the top level gene in the hierarchy specifies the spatial 
=
layout,
> connectivity, and number of elements of the gene just below it.  =

Is anyone
> familiar with any similar encoding algorithms?  The closest I =
can 
seem to
> find is what Xin Yao calls "parametric representations", and=
 cites 
Harp et
> al.
> 
> Any pointers or input would be helpful.
> 
> Tha=
nks,
> Derek
>
